PHONOLOGICAL WORD In Mixtepec Mixtec1 the minimal phonological word is made up of the sequence of two syllables - a couplet. This couplet is the complex nucleus of the word; the first syllable is marked phonologically by a lengthened vowel unless that vowel is preceding /?/: k[o.^lo^ko1 'our (excl.) male turkey', s[i.Ysiz-ei2 'his or her (child) aunt', .]3ko3-yu3 'my (polite) collarbone', ζ,[ΐ.]ΗαΖΛ 'sandal\ tizkw[a.]za2 'butterfly'; but, la?2la2-ei2 'his or her (child) mucus', ja1 ^al-m1 'your (sing, polite) gravy'. A hyphen has been placed after the couplet unless the couplet is final in the word. For example: ka1suz-nir 'you (sing, polite) are toasting (it)' versus tizkazsuz 'a toasted tortilla'; kaza2-ei2 'his or her (child) metal' versus vexkaza2 'a jail'; eizso2-ei2 'his or her (child) brother-in- law' versus 0izkuzci2 'a bat'; taxku2ni2 'yesterday' versus talkat-ni1 'your (sing, polite) woodpecker'. These contrast as in: eqlpyx 'y°u (sing, fam.) are smoking', eq1?y2 'is smoking', Ί (fam.) am smoking'; kwi3ka3-nix 'your (sing, polite) comb', kwi3ka3-ei2 'his or her (child) comb', kwi3ka3-ra3 'his (polite) comb'. Contrasts can also be demonstrated following the frames: 9i2p 'one', ?i3i3 'nine'; and when preceding kannu2 'big'. For example: yuxku3 'yoke', tu2tu3 'paper', kwi3ka3 'comb'; saxta2i dove', ma2cu2 'mule', ei3so2 'brother- in-law'. In two-syllable words with a medial consonant, eight different se- quences of single tones occur: lolcil 'buzzard', eoxko2 'possum', suxku3 'high'; ya2tax 'old', ya2ci2 'near', si2to3 'uncle'; si3kwi2 'milk', so3ko3 'collarbone'. The tone sequence 3 1 may occur when the second syllable consists of a vowel: ko3ox 'snake'. When, however, there is a medial consonant, the sequence 3 1 alternates to 3-2 1 and 3-1 1 as in: ji3!3' 2/3-ifcMi 'you (sing, fam.) are returning'. When the tone sequence 3 1 occurs between words, however, that alternation does not occur: tu2tu3 Jaxax 'blue paper', kwi3ka3 kannu2 'big comb'. We have distinguished between a TONE SEQUENCE in which the tones occur on successive syllables and a TONE CLUSTER in which the tones occur on a single syllable. There are four tone clusters: 3-1, 3-2, 1-3, and 2-3. The clusters 2-1 and 1-2 do not occur. The cluster 3-2 does not occur on a word-final syllable. TONE VARIANTS Tone variants may be conditioned by the vowel with which the tone occurs. The vowel /if usually has a higher pitch than the other vowels in the same environments: va3ei2 su3tu3 'a priest is coming' versus ku3na2 su3tu3 'a priest is opening (it)'; du2ku1-ko2yi1 'they (fem. fam.) are looking for' versus du2kux-ko2yux 'you (pi. fam.) are looking for'; i-3 ' m y (fam.) leg' versus s p ' h i s (fam.) leg'; tq19q3 'my (fam.) relative' versus tql p{'3 'his (fam.) relative'. Lower allotones frequently occur with nasal vowels: cjj3y2 'hen', versus yu3u2 'stone'; kwix'3ix 'narrow' versus k«tfi-3/ι 'green'. Even within repetitions of the same word, there is considerable variation in the pitch of tone 1. Tone 1 has a raised allotone when contiguously preceding tone 2, and it is raised even higher when preceding tone 3: kollox ka91nu2 'big male turkey', tixsix eolko2 'a possum is whining' (the third syllables are the highest); koxlox-ra3 'his (polite) male turkey', koxlox-ei2 'his or her (child) male turkey' (the second syllables are the highest). When two clusters of 1-3 occur in the same word, the first has the higher allotone: kal'3sa13 Ί (fam.) am sneezing', six-3ni13 'my (fam.) hat'. Tone 1 is lowered when it occurs as part of the tone cluster 3-1. The tone cluster 3-1 varies between a short upglide and a level allotone: ku3mi3-xya2?ax 'four eagles'. (See the paragraph on the description of the allotones of the 3-1 cluster for further details of the variants.) Tone 2 has a raised allotone when contiguously preceding tone 3: le92lu2-ras 'his (polite) lamb' (the second syllable is the highest). When part of the tone cluster 3-2, the tone 2 is lowered: ti32na3 'dog', du3~2si3 'honey', sa32a3 'beard'. (See the paragraph on the description of the allotones of the 3-2 cluster for further details of the variants.)
